sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: An important principle behind &argouml; is that actions should be able to be invoked in whatever way the user finds convenient. As a result many (but not all) actions that can be carried out on the menu can be carried out in other ways as well under &argouml;.
A number of the common menu entries are also available through keyboard shortcuts.

warning.para: It should also be possible to navigate the menu from the keyboard, Motif style. Each level of each menu is identified by a letter (shown underlined in the menu or entry name). This sequence of letters while holding down the ALT key should select the entry. In the current version of &argouml; this functionality is only available when running under Microsoft Windows.

sect1.title: The File Menu
sect1.para: These are actions concerned with input and output and the overall management of projects and the &argouml; system.

sect2.title: New…
sect2.para: Shortcut Ctrl-N.
This initializes a new project within &argouml;. The project is created with the name untitledModel and with two empty diagrams: a class diagram and a use case diagram.

note.para: Although the entry is named New… there is no dialog—the project is just created. The entry should properly be just New.

caution.para: untitledModel is not a valid model name (upper case is not permitted). See for a discussion of this.

sect2.title: Open Project…
sect2.para: Shortcut Ctrl-O.

figure.title: The file selection dialog for Open Project….

textobject.para: A file selection diagram showing directory selector; buttons to move up a directory, go to home directory, create a new director, change between list and details representations; filtered directory contents; filename text box; filename filter; and buttons to open and cancel.

sect2.para:
At the top of the dialog is a drop down selector labeled Look in:, specifying the currently selected directory preceded by the folder icon,
. The drop down selector gives access to all directories above this directory.

Next to this are four icons:
to move up a directory;
to select the users home directory,
to specify that a simple file list is displayed; and
(which is always grayed out) that would show details of all files if enabled.

The main body of the dialog is a text area with a listing of all files in the currently selected directory which match the current filter (see below). If these will not all fit on the display, scroll bars are provided to move up and down.

In the lower portion of the dialog is a text box labeled File name: for the name of the file to be opened. The file name may be typed directly in here, or selected from the directory listing above using &button1; click.

Beneath this is a drop down selector labeled Files of type: to specify a filter on the files to be shown in the directory listing. Only files that match the filter are listed. The available filters are:

listitem.para: all files;
zipped Argo project files (the default);
Argo project files; and
XMI format files.

sect2.para: Argo project files are produced by earlier releases of &argouml;, XMI files allow you to use diagrams from other tools (which may not always work!).
To the right of the file name and filter are two buttons, Open and Cancel to open the selected project or cancel the operation.

note.para: Open will only succeed if a valid filename is provided.

sect2.title: Save Project
sect2.para: Shortcut Ctrl-S.
This saves the project using its current file name.

sect2.title: Save Project As…
sect2.para: This opens a dialog allowing you to save the project under a different file name (or to specify a file name for the first time if you are a new project).

caution.para: If you are using an experimental version of &argouml; you will receive a warning message that file formats are not guaranteed to be supported in the long term. You should be cautious about using unstable versions of the system for important projects.

sect2.para: The dialog box is identical to that for Open Project (see ). The Files of type: also specifies the file type used for saving, and you should choose a filename with the corresponding ending.

tip.para: Zipped Argo Project files, ending in .zargo (the default) are the most efficient way of saving projects. They capture all the model and graphical information in a very compact format.

sect2.title: Import…
sect2.para: This sub-menu provides access to mechanisms to import a variety of material in to &argouml;. In the current version of &argouml; only one type of import is provided as standard, the importing of Java code for reverse engineering.

note.para: Despite being named Import… there is no dialog box associated with the Import menu itself (there may be with the sub-menu entries). It should strictly speaking be labeled just Import on the menu.

sect3.title: Import Sources…
sect3.para: A very powerful feature of &argouml; is that it can Reverse Engineer Java code to yield a class diagram. This sub-menu entry specifies Java code to be imported for reverse engineering.

figure.title: The file selection dialog for Import Sources….

textobject.para: A file selection diagram for importing sources showing directory selector; buttons to move up a directory, go to home directory, create a new directory, change between list and details representations; filtered directory contents; tabs for general and Java specific information; filename text box; filename filter; and buttons to open and cancel.

caution.para: The only file filter provided selects all files. However reverse engineering is currently only available, and Java source files only should be selected.

sect3.para: The first of the two tabs is labeled General and is selected by &button1; click on its tab. It provides a single check box Descend directories recursively. If enabled (the default), reverse engineering will track through sub-directories for any further Java files. If not it will restrict to the selected directory.
The second of the two tabs is labeled Java and is selected by &button1; click on its tab. It provides two pairs of radio boxes.
The first radio box allows selection between modeling attributes of Java classes as UML attributes (the default) or as UML associations to the class specified.
The second radio box allows selection between modeling arrays as v new datatypes in their own right (the default) or as their base datatype with multiplicity.

sect2.title: Load Model From DB
sect2.para: ArgoUML has the ability to save models to and from an SQL database. However the code for this is quite old, and at present this menu option is grayed out.

sect2.title: Save Model To DB
sect2.para: ArgoUML has the ability to save models to and from an SQL database. However the code for this is quite old, and at present this menu option is grayed out.

sect2.title: Print…
sect2.para: Shortcut Ctrl-P.
This brings up a dialog box allowing the &argouml; model to be printed out.

warning.para: In the current release of &argouml; this function behaves strangely if you have no printer configured under Linux. A small dialog box appears, but it has no functionality.

sect2.title: Save Graphics…
sect2.para: This menu entry brings up a dialog box allowing the currently selected diagram (in the editing pane) to be saved in one of a number of graphic formats.
The dialog box is identical to that for Open Project (see ). The Files of type: also specifies the graphics type used for saving, and you should choose a filename with the corresponding ending.
The available graphics types are:

listitem.para: GIF (the default);
Postscript;
Encapsulated Postscript; and
Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG).

sect2.para: The filter also allows you to specify all files, in which case the file type is deduced from the filename ending.

caution.para: You should be aware that there are patent issues surrounding GIF files and act accordingly. There are currently no such concerns about SVG.

warning.para: If you use the all files filter and specify a filename ending that &argouml; does not support (i.e. anything other than .gif, .ps, .eps and .svg) &argouml; will silently do nothing.

sect2.title: Save Configuration
sect2.para: &argouml; has various user specific configurations that can be set, both through the Settings… entry on the Edit menu (see ) and directly on the various panes. This menu entry saves the information in the file argo.user.properties in the users home directory.

tip.para: This is a text file, which you can edit to configure &argouml;.

sect2.title: Exit
sect2.para: Shortcut Alt-F4.
This closes down &argouml; A warning message will pop-up if you have a project open with unsaved changes asking if you wish to save it. The three options are:

listitem.para: Yes (save the project and exit &argouml;);
No (do not save the project, but still exit &argouml;); and
Cancel (do not save the project and do not exit &argouml;).

sect1.title: The Edit Menu
sect1.para: This menu provides support for selecting artifacts on the editing pane; an undo/redo function; cut, copy and paste functions; removal of artifacts from diagrams and the model; and control of user settings.

sect2.title: The Select Sub-Menu
sect2.para: This sub-menu provides for selection of items on the editing menu. It has four entries.

listitem.para: Select All (shortcut Ctrl-A). Selects all artifacts on the editing pane.
Select Previous. &argouml; has a concept of the ordering of artifacts on a diagram. This selects the item prior to the currently selected item in that ordering.

caution.para: The behavior of this menu function can be very strange, selecting items that do not appear to be on any diagram. It is probably best avoided.

listitem.para: Select Next. Similarly this selects the item following the currently selected item in that ordering.

caution.para: Again the behavior of this menu function can be very strange, selecting items that do not appear to be on any diagram. It is probably best avoided.

listitem.para: Invert Selection. This inverts the current selection (i.e. everything that was selected is de-selected and everything that was not selected is selected).

sect2.title: Undo
sect2.para: This is intended to undo editing actions.

warning.para: In the current implementation of &argouml; this function is not available and is permanently grayed out.

sect2.title: Redo
sect2.para: This is intended to redo editing actions—that is to reverse the effect of the Undo function.

warning.para: In the current implementation of &argouml; this function is not available and is permanently grayed out.

sect2.title: Cut
sect2.para: Shortcut Ctrl-X.
This should take the currently selected items, remove them from the diagram, and place them on the clipboard for subsequent pasting.

warning.para: In the current implementation of &argouml; there are some difficulties with clipboard based functions. This menu option is permanently grayed out.

sect2.title: Copy
sect2.para: Shortcut Ctrl-C.
This should take the currently selected items and make a copy of them on the clipboard for subsequent pasting.

warning.para: If the original item is deleted from the model or removed from the diagram, subsequent pasting will produce a copy that has no namespace, and cannot be properly saved.
In addition pasting back to the diagram from which the copy was made will replace the original, rather than duplicating it.
In the light of this, the copy function is best avoided.

sect2.title: Paste
sect2.para: Shortcut Ctrl-V.
This should paste the item(s) last cut or copied to the clipboard on to the currently diagram in the drawing pane.

warning.para: If the original item has since been deleted from the model or removed from the diagram, pasting will produce a copy that has no namespace, and cannot be properly saved.
In addition pasting back to the diagram from which the copy was made will replace the original, rather than duplicating it.
In the light of this, the paste function is best avoided.

sect2.title: Remove From Diagram
sect2.para: Shortcut Ctrl-R.
This function should remove the currently selected item(s) from the diagram, but not from the model.

warning.para: In the current version of &argouml; there is a known problem with this function. In some circumstances the item(s) are deleted from the model completely, not just from the diagram.

para.emphasis: You are strongly advised to save your diagram prior to using this function.

sect2.title: Delete From Model
sect2.para: Shortcut Delete.
This function deletes the selected item(s) from the model completely.

caution.para: In the current version of &argouml; the item(s) may not disappear from diagrams other than the current one. However the copies on other diagrams will have no associated properties. They should be deleted.

sect2.title: Empty trash
sect2.para: This menu function has no discernible effect. It is believed to invoke a garbage collection in the Java system.

sect2.title: Settings…

textobject.para: A dialog box for editing user settings, showing: four tabs (Preferences, Environment, User and Notation) in the main body and beneath them three buttons, OK, Cancel and Apply.

sect2.para: The options that can be set up on the various tabs are described in the following sections. For each tab there are three buttons at the bottom of the dialog box.

listitem.para: Cancel. Selecting this button (&button1; click) exits the dialog without applying any settings changed since the last Apply (or since the dialog started if Apply has not been used).
Apply. Selecting this button (&button1; click) applies the chosen settings and remains in the dialog.

sect2.para: These settings can be saved for use by subsequent &argouml; sessions (see ).

sect3.title: Preferences Tab
sect3.para: Selecting the Preferences tab (&button1; click on the tab) gives four options as check boxes.

listitem.para: Show Splash Panel (set by default). If enabled &argouml; will show a small panel with a picture while loading.

tip.para: The splash panel can be seen by using the Help menu (see ).

listitem.para: Preload Common Classes (set by default). If enabled &argouml; creates class objects of a number of classes internally during start up so that instantiation is quicker when they are needed.
Report Usage Statistics (set by default). If enabled usage statistics are reported on the console.

caution.para: In the current version of &argouml; there is only a very small amount of information, which may be missed amongst the other console output.

listitem.para: Report on Load Times (clear by default). If enabled load times at start up for the various phases of initialization are reported.

caution.para: These times are only of use to developers—they have no meaning to the ordinary user.

sect3.title: Environment Tab
sect3.para: Selecting the Environment tab (&button1; click on the tab) lists seven environmental items. Note that none of these can be set—this tab is just a matter of record.

listitem.para: ${argo.root}. The directory holding the top level argo class definitions. By default the classes sub-directory of the &argouml; build directory.
${argo.home}. The &argouml; build directory.
${argo.ext.dir}. The directory holding &argouml; extensions—by default the ext sub-directory of the &argouml; build directory.
${java.home}. The home directory of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE).
${user.home}. The user's home directory.
${user.dir}. The directory from which &argouml; was started.
startup directory. The directory in which &argouml; starts file searches etc.

sect3.title: User Tab
sect3.para: This tab allows the user to record additional information of use to the system. There are two text boxes provided.

listitem.para: Full Name:. Allows the user to record their full name.
Email Address:. Allows the user to record their Email address.

sect3.para: This information is used when requesting to-do help by Email.

sect3.title: Notation Tab
sect3.para: This tab allows the user to specify certain notation settings. It comprises two check boxes.

listitem.para: Only allow strict UML notation text (clear by default). This feature is for future use. One possibility is that a designer may create a diagram and indicate that the notation of the diagram is Java. Someone viewing the diagram with strict UML notation checked will only see UML notation in the classes no matter what notation the designer has used. See also ).

warning.para: This is not currently supported and is not a commitment to the feature of assigning a notation to a diagram either.

listitem.para: Use guillemots (« ») for stereotypes (clear by default). By default &argouml; uses pairs of less than and greater than (<< >>) characters for stereotypes If this box is checked stereotypes on diagrams are shown between true guillemots (« »).

caution.para: This feature is not fully implemented in the current version of &argouml;.

sect1.title: The View Menu
sect1.para: This menu is used for actions that affect how the various panes are viewed.

sect2.title: Goto Diagram…

textobject.para: A dialog box for Goto Diagram. It shows a single tab labeled All Diagrams containing a table with four columns and one row for each diagram in the current project, with a scroll bar to the right. The four columns are labeled from left to right Type, Name, In Diagram and Description.

sect2.para: The dialog box is in the form of a tab containing a table with four columns and one row for each diagram in the current project. A scroll bar gives access if the list is too long for the box. Double &button1; click on any row will select that diagram in the editing pane. The four columns are as follows.

listitem.para: Type. Lists the type of diagram.

caution.para: In the current release of &argouml; activity diagrams, collaboration diagrams, sequence diagrams and deployment diagrams are all listed as type Diagram.

listitem.para: Name. Lists the name given to the diagram.
In Diagram. This shows the diagram in which the digram is contained. Since diagrams cannot be contained within other diagrams, this always shows the entry N/A.

tip.para: This column is present, because this menu item reuses the code for the more general Find menu.

listitem.para: Description. Shows how many nodes and edges there are on the diagrams. The number of 2-D artifacts and the number of connector artifacts respectively.

sect2.title: Find…

textobject.para: A dialog box for Find. It shows four tabs labeled Name and Location, Last Modified, Tagged Values and Constraints. Of these all but the first are grayed out. There are then two edit boxes with drop-downs labeled Element Name: and In Diagram:, both with the default entry *. Below these two is a selection box labeled Search In: and with the default selection Entire Project. To the right is a selection box labeled Element Type with the default selection Any Type. There are then two buttons labeled Clear Tabs and Search. The lower two thirds of the screen shows a number of tabs, the first labeled Help. In the diagram two are shown, with the second selected, labeled * in * reflecting a search for any element name in any diagram. The top half of the tab is labeled Search Results: 1 items and contains a table with four columns labeled Type, Name. In Diagram and Description. A single row is shown in this table with the four columns containing respectively Model, diagrams, N/A and docs. The lower half of the tab is labeled Related Elements: and contains a table with the same four columns, but with no data.

warning.para: In the current version of &argouml; this function is largely broken. The only item that can ever be found is the model itself, and it is not possible (or meaningful) to navigate to this item's diagram.

sect2.para: At the top level, the dialog box has four tabs labeled Name and Location, Last Modified, Tagged Values and Constraints. Of these all but the first are grayed out, so the first tab is always selected.

The tab is split into three areas vertically. The top third specifies the search to be made. A text box labeled Element Name: specifies the name of the element (or artifact) to search for. Wild cards (*, ?) may be used here. A drop down gives access to search expressions previously used. A text box labeled In Diagram: specifies which diagrams are to be searched. Again wild cards may be used. Both these two text boxes have a default entry of *, i.e. match anything.
To the right of these two text boxes, a selector labeled Element Type: allows you to specify the UML metaclass for which you are searching.

caution.para: The names in of the element types use the NovoSoft UML convention, being the UML metaclass name preceded by M. Not all metaclasses are available.

sect2.para: A selector labeled Entire Project allows the search to be made over the entire project (the default) or as a sub-search over the results of a previous search.
Beneath these boxes are two buttons.

listitem.para: Clear Tabs. This clears the display of tabs with the results from previous searches (see below). The results are still available however for sub-searching.
Search. This causes the search specified in the text boxes and selectors above to be executed. The results are displayed in a tab taking up the lower two thirds of the page.

sect2.para: The lower two thirds of the dialog comprises an initial tab (labeled Help) giving summary help, and further tabs displaying the results of searches. These search tabs are labeled with a summary of the search element in diagram and are divided horizontally in two halves.
The top half is labeled Search Results: followed by a count of the number of items found. It comprises a table with one row for each element (artifact) and four columns.

listitem.para: Type. Lists the type of element (artifact).
Name. Lists the name given to the element (artifact).
In Diagram. Where the artifact is visible on a diagram, this lists the name of the diagram, otherwise it shows N/A.

caution.para: The behavior when an item is on more than one diagram is unknown.

listitem.para: Description. Contains a description of the element (artifact). At present this seems to be restricted to the single entry docs.

sect2.para: &Button1; click on any row will give more information on that artifact and show related artifacts in the bottom half (see below). Double click on any row describing an artifact on a diagram and that item and diagram will be selected.

The bottom half of the tab is a table labeled Related Elements: and is a table with the same columns as the top half. When an element (artifact) has been selected in the top half, this table shows the details of any related elements.

sect2.title: The Zoom Sub-Menu
sect2.para: This entry brings up a sub-entry, which scales the view of the current diagram to a given percentage of its notional size.
The sub-menu values that can be selected are 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%, 125%, 150%.
When created all diagrams are at a zoom level of 100%.

warning.para: The current version of &argouml; has a known problem, where zoom may not work on some diagrams.

sect2.title: The Editor Tabs Sub-Menu
sect2.para: The editing pane is conceived as a multi-mode editor, allowing you to edit a UML diagram from a number of perspectives.

listitem.para: As a diagram. This views the diagram in conventional graphical terms and is the default.
As a table. The artifacts on the diagram are listed in a table with a column for each of their properties, which may be edited.
As metrics. This representation is yet to be defined and is not currently available in &argouml;.

sect2.para: The various representations may be selected by &button1; click on the corresponding tab at the bottom of the editing pane. Since the current version of &argouml; only supports a diagram representation, there is only one tab labeled As Diagram.
The Editor Tabs sub-menu has four entries.

listitem.para: Next Editing Tab (shortcut F6). Selects the next tab on the editing pane.

caution.para: Since there is only one editing tab in the current version of &argouml;, As Diagram, this always selects that representation, and is thus a null operation.

listitem.para: As Diagram (shortcut Alt+Shift-1). Selects the As Diagram tab on the editing pane.
As Table (shortcut Alt+Shift-2). Selects the As Table tab on the editing pane.

caution.para: Since table representation is not supported in the current version of &argouml; this entry is always grayed out and not available.

listitem.para: As Metrics (shortcut Alt+Shift-3). Selects the As Metrics tab on the editing pane.

caution.para: Since metrics representation is not supported in the current version of &argouml; this entry is always grayed out and not available.

sect2.title: The Details Tabs Sub-Menu
sect2.para: This provides a sub-menu allowing selection of the various tabs on the details pane for the currently selected artifact. The sub-menu has nine entries.

listitem.para: Next Details Tab (shortcut F5). Selects the next available tab in the details pane.

note.para: If a tab is not available, it is skipped (for example a diagram text box only has ToDoItem, Properties and Source tabs, with all other tabs grayed out).

listitem.para: ToDoItem (shortcut Alt-1). Selects the ToDoItem tab for the currently selected artifact.
Properties (shortcut Alt-2). Selects the Properties tab for the currently selected artifact.

caution.para: The Properties tab will be selected even if it is not available for the current artifact, in which case it will be completely blank.

listitem.para: Javadocs (shortcut Alt-3). Selects the Javadocs tab for the currently selected artifact.

warning.para: The current version of &argouml; has no Javadocs tab, so this entry is always grayed out.

listitem.para: Source (shortcut Alt-4). Selects the Source tab for the currently selected artifact.

caution.para: The Source tab will be selected even if it is not available for the current artifact, in which case it will just hold the grayed out text Nothing selected

listitem.para: Constraints (shortcut Alt-5). Selects the Constraints tab for the currently selected artifact.

warning.para: The Constraints tab will be selected even if it is not available for the current artifact, in which case it will present a standard constraints tab with no entries. The side effects of entering any data are unknown.

listitem.para: Tagged Values (shortcut Alt-6). Selects the Tagged Values tab for the currently selected artifact.

warning.para: The Tagged Values tab will be selected even if it is not available for the current artifact, in which case it will contain arbitrary data. The side effects of altering this data are unknown.

listitem.para: Checklist (shortcut Alt-7). Selects the Checklist tab for the currently selected artifact.

caution.para: The Checklist tab will be selected even if it is not available for the current artifact, in which case it will be completely blank.

listitem.para: History (shortcut Alt-8). Selects the History tab for the currently selected artifact.

warning.para: The current version of &argouml; has no History tab, so this entry is always grayed out.

sect2.title: Adjust Grid
sect2.para: This cycles the grid representation on the screen through the following sequence:

listitem.para: dots at 16 pixel spacing (the default);
dots at 32 pixel spacing;
no grid of any form;
full grid at 16 pixel spacing; and
full grid at 8 pixel spacing.

sect2.title: Adjust Grid Snap
sect2.para: This cycles the spacing of grid snapping through the following sequence:

listitem.para: snap at 8 pixel spacing (the default);
snap at 16 pixel spacing;
snap at 32 pixel spacing; and
snap at 4 pixel spacing.

note.para: There is no option to turn of snap to grid altogether

caution.para: In the current version of &argouml; this is not actually a true snap to grid. It just defines the increments by which artifacts are moved around. Thus if an item has an X coordinate of 4 and Grid Snap is set to 8, moving will take it to X coordinates of 12, 20, 28 etc, not 8, 16, 24 etc
If you wish to align on true grid snap boundaries, you can use the Arrange > Align To Grid menu (see ).

sect2.title: Adjust Page Breaks
sect2.para: This toggles whether page breaks are shown on the diagram (as white dotted lines).

caution.para: This is incorrectly named and implemented in the current version of &argouml;, since there is no mechanism to alter the page breaks. It should be a tick box toggle labeled Page Breaks Visible

sect2.title: Buttons on Selection
sect2.para: If this menu option is enabled, certain artifacts on diagrams will display graphic handles when selected that can be dragged to create connections of various types (associations, generalizations) to other artifacts.

caution.para: The menu entry is somewhat misleading labeled. It is better thought of as Handles On Selection.

sect2.title: The Notation Sub-Menu
sect2.para: This sub-menu presents a radio box with two options.

note.para: This feature is not completely handled throughout &argouml;, primarily because the multi-notation support is still rather new. See also ).

sect2.para: In the future, this feature will define the user's default notation. At some point &argouml; will allow defining a class in a diagram as being represented using a specific notation.

For example a class Able which is represented in Java, and class Baker which is represented in C++, with class Able using class Baker and a class Charlie which references Able, but does not have a specific notation defined for the diagram element.

In this situation, Charlie would be represented in the default notation, while Able and Baker would be represented as defined in the diagram element. Changing the default notation would cause Charlie's notation to change but not Able or Baker.

listitem.para: Uml.1.3. Uses UML notation as the default notation for classes.
Java. Uses Java notation as the default notation for classes.

sect1.title: The Create Diagram Menu
sect1.para: This menu provides for creating the various types of UML diagrams supported by &argouml;.

sect2.title: Class Diagram
sect2.para: This menu entry creates a blank class diagram, and selects that diagram in the editing pane. If a package is currently selected, the class diagram will be created within that package, it will be shown within the package on the navigation pane hierarchy (under Package-centric view) and artifacts created on the diagram will have the namespace of the package.

tip.para: This does not prevent artifacts from other namespaces/packages appearing on the diagram. They can added from the navigation pane using Add to Diagram from the &button2; pop-up menu.

sect2.title: Use Case Diagram
sect2.para: This menu entry creates a blank use case diagram, and selects that diagram in the editing pane. If a package is currently selected, the use case diagram will be created within that package, it will be shown within the package on the navigation pane hierarchy (under Package-centric view) and artifacts created on the diagram will have the namespace of the package.

tip.para: This does not prevent artifacts from other namespaces/packages appearing on the diagram. They can added from the navigation pane using Add to Diagram from the &button2; pop-up menu.

sect2.title: State Diagram
sect2.para: This menu entry creates a blank state diagram associated with the currently selected class, and selects that diagram in the editing pane. Artifacts created on the diagram will have the namespace of the owning class.

caution.para: State diagrams must be associated with a class. In the current version of &argouml; the State Diagram menu entry is not grayed out if a class is not selected. However invoking the menu entry will have no effect.

sect2.title: Activity Diagram
sect2.para: This menu entry creates a blank activity diagram associated with the currently selected class, and selects that diagram in the editing pane. Artifacts created on the diagram will have the namespace of the owning class.

caution.para: Activity diagrams must be associated with a class. In the current version of &argouml; the Activity Diagram menu entry is not grayed out if a class is not selected. However invoking the menu entry will have no effect.

sect2.title: Collaboration Diagram
sect2.para: This menu entry creates a blank collaboration diagram, and selects that. Within the package hierarchy, collaboration diagrams are always created within a Collaboration, within the package or model, rather than within the package or model directly itself. If a package is current selected, the collaboration diagram will be created within a collaboration within that package, it will be shown within the collaboration within the package on the navigation pane hierarchy (under Package-centric view) and artifacts created on the diagram will have the namespace of the collaboration within the package.

tip.para: This does not prevent artifacts from other namespaces/packages appearing on the diagram. They can added from the navigation pane using Add to Diagram from the &button2; pop-up menu.

sect2.title: Deployment Diagram
sect2.para: This menu entry creates a blank deployment diagram, and selects that diagram in the editing pane. If a package is current selected, the deployment diagram will be created within that package, it will be shown within the package on the navigation pane hierarchy (under Package-centric view) and artifacts created on the diagram will have the namespace of the package.

tip.para: This does not prevent artifacts from other namespaces/packages appearing on the diagram. They can added from the navigation pane using Add to Diagram from the &button2; pop-up menu.

sect2.title: Sequence Diagram
sect2.para: This menu entry creates a blank sequence diagram, and selects that diagram in the editing pane. If a package is current selected, the sequence diagram will be created within that package, it will be shown within the package on the navigation pane hierarchy (under Package-centric view) and artifacts created on the diagram will have the namespace of the package.

tip.para: This does not prevent artifacts from other namespaces/packages appearing on the diagram. They can added from the navigation pane using Add to Diagram from the &button2; pop-up menu.

sect1.title: The Arrange Menu
sect1.para: This menu provides a range of functions to help in the alignment of artifacts on diagrams within the editing pane. In general the menu function invoked is applied to any artifact or artifacts currently selected in the editing pane.

sect2.title: The Align Sub-Menu
sect2.para: This sub-menu aligns the selected items. There are seven alignment options provided.

listitem.para: Align Tops. Aligns the selected artifacts by their top edges.
Align Bottoms. Aligns the selected artifacts by their bottom edges.
Align Lefts. Aligns the selected artifacts by their left edges.
Align Rights. Aligns the selected artifacts by their right edges.
Align Horizontal Centers. Aligns the selected artifacts so their horizontal centers are in a vertical line.
Align Vertical Centers. Aligns the selected artifacts so their vertical centers are in a horizontal line.
Align To Grid. Aligns the selected artifacts so their top and right edges are on the grid snap boundary (see ) edge.

caution.para: The alignment is to the current grid snap setting, which may be smaller, larger or the same as the displayed grid. Since items are aligned to the grid snap boundary any way when you place them, this menu entry has no effect unless you have either changed the grid snap to a larger value or used one of the other Arrange menu entries to push items off their initial positions.

sect2.title: The Distribute Sub-Menu
sect2.para: This sub-menu distributes the selected items. There are four distribution options provided.

listitem.para: Distribute Horizontal Spacing. The leftmost and rightmost selected artifacts are not moved. The others are adjusted horizontally until the horizontal space (i.e. from the right edge of the left artifact to the left edge of the right artifact) is the same for all of the selected items

Distribute Horizontal Centers. The leftmost and rightmost selected artifacts are not moved. The others are adjusted horizontally until the distance between the horizontal centers of all the selected items is the same.

Distribute Vertical Spacing. The top and bottom selected artifacts are not moved. The others are adjusted vertically until the vertical space (i.e. from the bottom edge of the top artifact to the top edge of the bottom artifact) is the same for all of the selected items

Distribute Vertical Centers. The top and bottom selected artifacts are not moved. The others are adjusted vertically until the distance between the vertical centers of all the selected items is the same.

sect2.title: The Reorder Sub-Menu
sect2.para: This sub-menu adjusts the ordering of overlapping items. There are four reorder options provided.

listitem.para: To Back. The selected artifacts are moved to the back of any other artifacts they overlap.
To Front. The selected artifacts are moved to the front of any other artifacts they overlap.
Backward. The selected artifacts are moved one step back in the ordering hierarchy with respect to other artifacts they overlap.
Forward. The selected artifacts are moved one step forward in the ordering hierarchy with respect to other artifacts they overlap.

sect2.title: The Nudge Sub-Menu
sect2.para: This sub-menu provides fine adjustment to the positioning of selected artifacts. There are four nudge options provided.

listitem.para: Nudge Left. The selected artifacts are moved one pixel to the left.
Nudge Right. The selected artifacts are moved one pixel to the right.
Nudge Up. The selected artifacts are moved one pixel to the up.
Nudge Down. The selected artifacts are moved one pixel to the down.

sect2.title: The Layout Sub-Menu
sect2.para: This provides control of layout of items on class diagrams during reverse engineering (see ). It provides two options.

listitem.para: Automatic. Automated layout.
Incremental. Incremental layout.

caution.para: For all except class diagrams, the two menu entries are grayed out and unavailable (since reverse engineering only creates a class diagram). For class diagrams only the Automatic option is available. So the utility of this menu entry is somewhat limited.

sect1.title: The Generation Menu
sect1.para: This menu provides support for code generation from UML diagrams. The functionality is built around the structural information of class diagrams.

note.para: The current version of &argouml; supports only code generation of Java. Future work will extend this to other languages.

caution.para: This is still very much work in progress. The current version of &argouml; will generate a structural template for your code, but is not able to handle behavioral specifications to generate code for the dynamic behavior of the model.

sect2.title: Generate Selected Classes

figure.title: The dialog for Generate Selected Classes.

textobject.para: A dialog box for Generate Selected Classes. Below a label Generate Classes: it lists each of the selected classes by name with a check box to the left. At the bottom is a text box labeled Output Directory: containing the directory in which code is generated with a drop down selector giving access to previously selected output directories. Beneath this is a check box labeled compile generated source. At the bottom of the dialog box are two buttons, labeled from left to right Generate and Cancel.

sect2.para: Below a label Generate Classes: the dialog box lists each of the selected classes by name with a check box to the left, which is initially checked. Unchecking any of these boxes will omit code generation for that class.

In the lower portion of the dialog box is a text box labeled Output Directory: to specify the directory in which code is generated. Within this directory, a top level directory will be created with the name of the model. Further sub-directories will be created to reflect the package/namespace hierarchy of the model. A drop down selector gives access to previously selected output directories.
Beneath this a check box labeled compile generated source (clear by default) controls whether the generated code should be compiled.

Finally, at the bottom of the dialog box are two buttons, labeled Generate and Cancel. &Button1; on the former will cause the code to be generated, &button1; on the latter will cancel code generation.

note.para: Strictly speaking this menu entry should be labeled Generate Selected Classes…, since it invokes a dialog box.

sect2.title: Generate All Classes
sect2.para: Shortcut F7.
This function behaves as Generate Selected Classes (see ) would with all classes in the model selected.

sect1.title: The Critique Menu
sect1.para: This menu controls one of &argouml;'s unique features—the use of critics to guide the designer. The theory behind this is well described in Jason Robbins' PhD dissertation http://argouml.tigris.org/docs/robbins_dissertation/.

note.para: A word about terminology. The critics are background processes, which evaluate the current model according to various good design criteria. There is one critic for every design criterion.
The output of a critic is a critique—a statement about some aspect of the model that does not appear to follow good design practice.
Finally a critique will generally suggest how the bad design issue it has identified can be rectified, by raising a to-do item.
The critics run as asynchronous processes that run in parallel with the main &argouml; tool. Changes typically take a second or two to propagate as the critics wake up.

sect2.title: Toggle Auto-Critique
sect2.para: This is a check box, controlling whether the critics are running. By default it is checked. If unchecked, then all critics are disabled, and any to-do items generated by critics (the only others being those the designer has added by hand) are hidden in the to-do pane.

sect2.title: Design Issues…

textobject.para: A dialog box for Design Issues…. The body of the box contains a list with the name of a design issue to the left and a slider to the right labeled 5 at its left hand end. A scroll bar gives access to items of the list not displayed in the box. At the very bottom right is a button labeled OK.

sect2.para: &argouml; categorizes critics according the the design issue they address. At present there are 16 such categories.

listitem.para: Uncategorized. Unused.
Class Selection. Three critics.
Naming. Eighteen critics.
Storage. Four critics.
Planned Extensions. Three critics.
MState Machines. Fourteen critics.
Design Patterns. Sixteen critics.
Relationships. Seven critics.
Instantiation. Unused.
Modularity. Two critics.
Expected Usage.One critic.
Methods. Four critics.
Code Generation. One critic.
Stereotypes. Unused.
Inheritance. Ten critics.
Containment. Six critics.

sect2.para: The sliders may be set for each category to control the critics that trigger for that category. Setting a slider to zero will disable all critics in that category, and remove all associated to-do items from the to-do pane.
Setting a slider to a higher value will enable all critics at or above that priority level within the design issue category (1 being the highest priority and 5 the lowest.

note.para: The sliders are set by default to 5 for all design categories except Uncategorized which is set to 1.

caution.para: In the current release of &argouml; all critics trigger at priority 1, so any higher values of the slider make no difference.

sect3.title: Uncategorized
sect3.para: These are critics that do not fit into any other category.
The current version of &argouml; has no critics in this category.

sect3.title: Class Selection
sect3.para: These are critics concerning how classes are chosen and used.
The current version of &argouml; has three critics in this category.

listitem.para: Wrap DataType. Suggestion that a datatype actually be a full-blown class.
Reduce Classes in diagram <diagram>. Suggestion to improve readability by having fewer classes on a diagram.
Clean Up Diagram. Suggestion that the diagram could be improved by moving artifacts that are overlapping.

sect3.title: Naming
sect3.para: These are critics concerning the naming of artifacts. The current version of &argouml; has 18 critics in this category.

listitem.para: Resolve Association Name Conflict. Suggestion that two association names in the same namespace have the same name. This is not permitted in UML.
Revise Attribute Names to Avoid Conflict. Suggestion that two attribute names of a class have the same name. This is not permitted in UML.

note.para: This may be caused by inheritance of an attribute through a generalization relationship.

listitem.para: Change Names or Signatures in <artifact>. Suggestion that two or more operations in the specified class or interface have the same signature, which will prevent valid code generation.

Role name conflicts with member. A suggestions that good design avoids role names for associations that clash with attributes or operations of the source class. Roles may be realized in the code as attributes or operations, causing code generation problems.

Choose a Name (classes and interfaces). The class or interface concerned has been given no name (it will appear in the model as anon). Suggestion that good design requires that all interfaces and classes are named.

Chose a Unique Name for <artifact> (classes and interfaces). Suggestion that the class or interface specified has the same name as another (in the namespace), which is bad design and will prevent valid code generation.
Choose a name (attributes). The attribute concerned has been given no name (it will appear in the model as anon). Suggestion that good design requires that all attributes are named.
Choose a name (operations). The operation concerned has been given no name (it will appear in the model as anon). Suggestion that good design requires that all operations are named.
Choose a Name (states). The state concerned has been given no name (it will appear in the model as anon). Suggestion that good design requires that all states are named.

Choose a Unique Name for <artifact> (states). Suggestion that the state specified has the same name as another (in the current state diagram), which is bad design and will prevent valid code generation.
Revise Name to Avoid Confusion. Two names in the same namespace have very similar names (differing only by one character). Suggestion this could potentially lead to confusion.

caution.para: This critic can be particularly annoying, since at times it is useful and good design to have a series of artifacts var1, var2 etc.
It is important to remember that critics offer guidance, and are not always correct. &argouml; lets you dismiss the resulting to-do items through the to-do pane (see ).

listitem.para: Choose a Legal Name. All artifact names in &argouml; must use only letters, digits and underscore characters. This critic suggests an entity has not met this requirement.
Change <artifact> to a Non-Reserved Word. Suggestion that this artifact's name is the same as a reserved word in UML (or within one character of one), which is not permitted.
Choose a Better Operation Name. Suggestion that an operation has not followed the naming convention that operation names begin with lower case letters.

caution.para: Following the Java and C++ convention most designers give their constructors the same name as the class, which begins with an upper case character and so triggers this critic.
It is important to remember that critics offer guidance, and are not always correct. &argouml; lets you dismiss the resulting to-do items through the to-do pane (see ).

listitem.para: Choose a Better Attribute Name. Suggestion that an attribute has not followed the naming convention that attribute names begin with lower case letters.
Capitalize Class Name <class>. Suggestion that a class has not followed the naming convention that classes begin with upper case letters.

note.para: Although not triggering this critic, the same convention should apply to interfaces.

listitem.para: Revise Package Name <artifact>. Suggestion that a package has not followed the naming convention of using lower case letters with periods used to indicated sub-packages.

sect3.title: Storage
sect3.para: Critics concerning attributes of classes.
The current version of &argouml; has four critics in this category.

listitem.para: Revise Attribute Names to Avoid Conflict. Suggestion that two attribute names of a class have the same name. This is not permitted in UML.

note.para: This may be caused by inheritance of an attribute through a generalization relationship.

listitem.para: Add Instance Variables to <class>. Suggestion that no instance variables have been specified for the given class. Such classes may be created to specify static attributes and methods, but by convention should be given the stereotype «utility».

warning.para: In the current version of &argouml; this critic triggers for all classes whether or not they have attributes, so should be treated with caution.
It is important to remember that critics offer guidance, and are not always correct. &argouml; lets you dismiss the resulting to-do items through the to-do pane (see ).

listitem.para: Add Constructor to <class>. Suggestion that you have not yet added a constructor to this class. This critic assumes a constructor is an operation of the class, with the same name as the class, in the same namespace as the class, with a return type of void.

note.para: Good practice would also suggest that constructors ought to have the stereotype «create», but this critic does not check for this.

caution.para: The current release of &argouml; has a known defect in this critic, whereby a constructor will only be recognised if it has no return parameter at all. This will be fixed in the near future to accept return paramters with no type or type void

listitem.para: Reduce Attributes on <class>. Suggestion that the class has too many attributes for a good design, and is at risk of becoming a design bottleneck.

sect3.title: Planned Extensions
sect3.para: Critics concerning interfaces and subclasses.
The current version of &argouml; has three critics in this category.

listitem.para: Operations in Interfaces must be public. Suggestion that there is no point in having non-public operations in Interfaces, since they must be visible to be realized by a class.
Interfaces may only have operations. Suggestion that an interfaces has attributes defined. The UML standard defines interfaces to have operations.

caution.para: It is really a limitation of the current version of &argouml; that it allows you to add attributes to an interface in the first place.

listitem.para: Remove Reference to Specific Subclass. Suggestion that in a good design, a class should not reference its subclasses directly through attributes, operations or associations.

note.para: It is not clear why this category has the name Planned Extensions.

sect3.title: MState Machines
sect3.para: Critics concerning state machines.
The current version of &argouml; has 14 critics in this category.

listitem.para: Reduce Transitions on <state>. Suggestion given state is involved in so many transitions it may be a maintenance bottleneck.

Reduce States in machine <machine>. Suggestion that the given state machine has so many states as to be confusing and should be simplified (perhaps by breaking into several machines, or using a hierarchy).
Add Transitions to <state>. Suggestion that the given state requires both incoming and outgoing transitions.
Add Incoming Transitions to <artifact>. Suggestion that the given state requires incoming transitions.
Add Outgoing Transitions from <artifact>. Suggestion that the given state requires outgoing transitions.
Remove Extra Initial States. Suggestion that there is more than one initial state in the state machine or composite state, which is not permitted in UML.
Place an Initial State. Suggestion that there is no initial state in the state machine or composite state.
Add Trigger or Guard to Transition. Suggestion that a transition is missing either a trigger or guard, one at least of which is required for it to be taken.
Change Join Transitions. Suggestion that the join pseudostate has an invalid number of transitions. Normally there should be one outgoing and two or more incoming.
Change Fork Transitions. Suggestion that the fork pseudostate has an invalid number of transitions. Normally there should be one incoming and two or more outgoing.
Change Branch Transitions. Suggestion that the branch pseudostate has an invalid number of transitions. Normally there should be one incoming and two or more outgoing.
Add Guard to Transition. Suggestion that the transition requires a guard.

caution.para: It is not clear that this is a valid critic. It is perfectly acceptable to have a transition without a guard—the transition is always taken when the trigger is invoked.

listitem.para: Clean Up Diagram. Suggestion that the diagram could be improved by moving artifacts that are overlapping.
Make Edge More Visible. Suggestion that an edge artifact such as an association or abstraction is so short it may be missed. Move the connected artifacts apart to make the edge more visible.

note.para: The correct title for this category should be State Machines.

sect3.title: Design Patterns
sect3.para: Critics concerning design pattern usage in &argouml;.

These relate to the use of patterns as described by the so called Gang of Four. &argouml; also uses this category for critics associated with deployment and sequence diagrams. The current version of &argouml; has 16 critics in this category.

listitem.para: Consider using Singleton Pattern for <artifact>. Suggestion that the class has many of the characteristics of a singleton class (i.e. only private constructors, static attribute to hold the instance, at least one constructor). Good design practice would suggest making this explicit by stereotyping with the «singleton» stereotype.

caution.para: By default &argouml; does not define the «singleton». You will need to define the stereotype before use (see ).

listitem.para: Singleton Stereotype Violated in <artifact>. Suggestion that the specified class, although declared with stereotype «singleton», does not have all the characteristics of a singleton class (i.e. only private constructors, static attribute to hold the instance, at least one constructor).

warning.para: In the current version of &argouml; this critic is always triggered for classes declared as «singleton», even if they meet all the required criteria. This is a known defect in the code.

listitem.para: Nodes normally have no enclosers. A suggestion that nodes should not be drawn inside other artifacts on the deployment diagram, since they represent an autonomous physical object.
NodeInstances normally have no enclosers. A suggestion that node instances should not be drawn inside other artifacts on the deployment diagram, since they represent an autonomous physical object.

Components normally are inside nodes. A suggestion that components represent the logical entities within physical nodes, and so should be drawn within a node, where nodes are shown on the deployment diagram.

ComponentInstances normally are inside nodes. A suggestion that component instances represent the logical entities within physical nodes, and so should be drawn within a node instance, where node instances are shown on the deployment diagram.
Classes normally are inside components. A suggestion that classes, as artifacts making up components, should be drawn within components on the deployment diagram.
Interfaces normally are inside components. A suggestion that interfaces, as artifacts making up components, should be drawn within components on the deployment diagram.
Objects normally are inside components. A suggestion that objects, as instances of artifacts making up components, should be drawn within components or component instances on the deployment diagram.

LinkEnds have not the same locations. A suggestion that a link (e.g. association) connecting objects on a deployment diagram has one end in a component and the other in a component instance (since objects can be in either). This makes no sense.
Set classifier (deployment diagram). Suggestion that there is an instance (object) without an associated classifier (class, datatype) on a deployment diagram.
Missing return-actions. Suggestion that a sequence diagram has a send or call action without a corresponding return action.
Missing call(send)-action. Suggestion that a sequence diagram has a return action, but no preceding call or send action.
No Stimuli on these links. Suggestion that a sequence diagram has a link connecting objects without an associated stimulus (without which the link is meaningless).

warning.para: Triggering this critic indicates a serious problem, since &argouml; provides no mechanism for creating a link without a stimulus. It probably indicates that the diagram was created by loading a corrupt project, with an XMI file describing a link without a stimulus, possibly created by a tool other than &argouml;.

listitem.para: Set classifier (sequence diagram). Suggestion that there is an object without an associated classifier (class, datatype) on a sequence diagram.
Wrong position of these stimuli. Suggestion that the initiation of send/call-return message exchanges in a sequence diagram does not properly initiate from left to right.

sect3.title: Relationships
sect3.para: Critics concerning associations in &argouml;.
The current version of &argouml; has seven critics in this category.

listitem.para: Circular Association. Suggestion that an association class has roles that refer back directly to itself, which is not permitted.

warning.para: This critic is meaningless in the current version of &argouml; which does not support association classes. In addition the current code would never trigger, even if an association class were created.

listitem.para: Make <association> Navigable. Suggestion that the association referred to is not navigable in either direction. This is permitted in the UML standard, but has no obvious meaning in any practical design.

Remove Navigation from Interface <interface>. Suggestion that the interface referred to, which connected by an association to a class, is navigable from the interface. This is not permitted in the UML standard.

caution.para: The current version of &argouml; has a known defect where it may create an association between a class and interface that is navigable from the interface, depending on the order in which the two ends are selected at the time of creation. The fix is to remove the navigation from the class end of the association if this critic is triggered.

listitem.para: Add Associations to <artifact>. Suggestion that the specified artifact (actor, use case or class) has no associations connecting it to other artifacts. This is required for the artifact to be useful in a design.
Remove Reference to Specific Subclass. Suggestion that in a good design, a class should not reference its subclasses directly through attributes, operations or associations.
Reduce Associations on <artifact> . Suggestion that the given artifact (actor, use case, class or interface) has so many associations it may be a maintenance bottleneck.
Make Edge More Visible. Suggestion that an edge artifact such as an association or abstraction is so short it may be missed. Move the connected artifacts apart to make the edge more visible.

sect3.title: Instantiation
sect3.para: Critics concerning instantiation of classifiers in &argouml;.
The current version of &argouml; has no critics in this category.

sect3.title: Modularity
sect3.para: Critics concerning modular development in &argouml;.
The current version of &argouml; has two critics in this category.

listitem.para: Aggregate Role in N-way Association. Suggestion that aggregation may not be used for associations with more than two ends.

warning.para: Whilst it is possible to create N-way associations in the current release of &argouml;, it is not supported graphically, and of little use. It is a known limitation of the current release that if you do create such associations, they will always trigger this critic, even if there is no aggregation on any end.

listitem.para: Add Elements to Package <package>. Suggestion that the specified package has no content. Good design suggests packages are created to put things in.

note.para: This will always trigger when you first create a package, since you cannot create one that is not empty!

sect3.title: Expected Usage
sect3.para: Critics concerning generally accepted good practice in &argouml;.
The current version of &argouml; has one critic in this category.

listitem.para: Clean Up Diagram. Suggestion that the diagram could be improved by moving artifacts that are overlapping.

sect3.title: Methods
sect3.para: Critics concerning operations in &argouml;.
The current version of &argouml; has four critics in this category.

listitem.para: Change Names or Signatures in <artifact>. Suggestion that two or more operations in the specified class or interface have the same signature, which will prevent valid code generation.
Class Must be Abstract. Suggestion that a class that inherits or defines abstract operations must be marked abstract.
Resolve Signature Conflict. Suggestion that two or more operations in the specified class or interface have the same signature, which will prevent valid code generation.
Reduce Operations on <artifact>. Suggestion that the artifact (class or interface) has too many operations for a good design, and is at risk of becoming a design bottleneck.

sect3.title: Code Generation
sect3.para: Critics concerning code generation in &argouml;.
The current version of &argouml; has one critic in this category.

listitem.para: Change Multiple Inheritance to interfaces. Suggestion that a class has multiple generalizations, which is permitted by UML, but cannot be generated into Java code, because Java does not support multiple inheritance.

sect3.title: Stereotypes
sect3.para: Critics concerning stereotypes in &argouml;.
The current version of &argouml; has no critics in this category.

sect3.title: Inheritance
sect3.para: Critics concerning generalization and specialization in &argouml;.
The current version of &argouml; has ten critics in this category.

listitem.para: Revise Attribute Names to Avoid Conflict. Suggestion that two attribute names of a class have the same name. This is not permitted in UML.

note.para: This may be caused by inheritance of an attribute through a generalization relationship.

listitem.para: Remove <class>'s Circular Inheritance. Suggestion that a class inherits from itself, through a chain of generalizations, which is not permitted.

caution.para: This critic is marked inactive by default in the current release of &argouml; (the only one so marked). It will not trigger unless made active.

listitem.para: Class Must be Abstract. Suggestion that a class that inherits or defines abstract operations must be marked abstract.
Remove final keyword or remove subclasses. Suggestion that a class that is final has specializations, which is not permitted in UML.
Illegal Generalization. Suggestion that there is a generalization between artifacts of different UML metaclasses, which is not permitted.

caution.para: It is not clear that such a generalization can be created within &argouml;. It probably indicates that the diagram was created by loading a corrupt project, with an XMI file describing such a generalization, possibly created by a tool other than &argouml;.

listitem.para: Remove Unneeded Realizes from <class>. Suggestion that the specified class has a realization relationship both directly and indirectly to the same interface (by realization from two interfaces, one of which is a generalization of the other for example). Good design deprecates such duplication.
Define Concrete (Sub)Class. Suggestion that a class is abstract with no concrete subclasses, and so can never be realized.
Define Class to Implement <interface>. Suggestion that the interface referred to has no influence on the running system, since it is never implemented by a class.

Change Multiple Inheritance to interfaces. Suggestion that a class has multiple generalizations, which is permitted by UML, but cannot be generated into Java code, because Java does not support multiple inheritance.
Make Edge More Visible. Suggestion that an edge artifact such as an association or abstraction is so short it may be missed. Move the connected artifacts apart to make the edge more visible.

sect3.title: Containment
sect3.para: Critics concerning containment in &argouml;, that is where one artifact forms a component part of another.
The current version of &argouml; has six critics in this category.

listitem.para: Remove Circular Composition. Suggestion that there is a series of composition relationships (associations with black diagrams) that form a cycle, which is not permitted.
Duplicate Parameter Name. Suggestion that a parameter list to an operation or event has two or more parameters with the same name, which is not permitted.
Multiple Aggregate Roles. Suggestion that more than one end of an association is aggregate or composite. At most one end should have multiplicity of any sort.
Aggregate Role in N-way Association. Suggestion that more than one end of an association is aggregate or composite. At most one end should have multiplicity of any sort.

caution.para: This appears to duplicate the critic Multiple Aggregate Roles within this design category.

listitem.para: Wrap DataType. Suggestion that a datatype actually be a full-blown class.
Import Parameter Type into Class. Suggestion that the type of a parameter used within an operation of a class is not visible.

warning.para: It is not clear how this can ever be caused within &argouml;. In any case this critic can never trigger in the current implementation of &argouml;.

sect2.title: Design Goals…
sect2.para: This menu entry brings up a dialog box controlling how design goals are to be handled (see ).

textobject.para: A dialog box for Design Goals…. The body of the box contains a list (in this example with only one entry) with the name of a design goal to the left and a slider to the right labeled 5 at its left hand end. At the very bottom right is a button labeled OK.

sect2.para: &argouml; has the concept that the designer will have a number of design goals to be achieved (for example good structural representation, detailed behavioral representation etc). Critics are associated with one or more goals.
This dialog allows the user to specify the priority of each design goal.

The sliders may be set for each design goal to control the critics that trigger for that goal. Setting a slider to zero will disable all critics in that goal, and remove all associated to-do items from the to-do pane.
Setting a slider to a higher value will enable all critics at or above that priority level within the design issue category (1 being the highest priority and 5 the lowest.

tip.para: It may be useful to think of this function as very similar to Design Issues… (see , but with grouping of critics according to the outcomes of &ooad; rather than grouping according to the structure of UML.

caution.para: The current version of &argouml; provides a single design goal, Unspecified, with its slider set by default to priority 1. However it contains no critics and so has no effect.

sect2.title: Browse Critics…
sect2.para: This menu entry brings up a dialog box controlling the individual critics (see ).

textobject.para: A dialog box for Browse Critics…. The left half of the dialog is a list titled Critics with one row for each critic. Each row has three columns, X, Headline and Active. A scroll bar to the right of the list gives access to parts of the list that are not visible. The right half of the dialog is a series of fields under the title Critic Class:. First is a text box labeled Headline: containing the headline text of the critic. Below that is a drop-down labeled Priority containing the priority of any to-do items generated by this critic. Next is a text box labeled MoreInfo: containing the URL that contains more information, and to its right a button (always grayed out) labeled Go. Beneath this is a text area labeled Description containing a detailed explanation of what the critic means, with a scroll bar to the right if the text is too big to fit in the box. Below this is a drop-down labeled Use Clarifier with three options available. Beneath this are three buttons in a row labeled from left to right Wake, Configure and Edit Network. Finally at the bottom left is a button labeled OK.

sect2.para: This dialog controls the behavior of individual critics. To the left is a list of all the critics. For each critic there are three columns, labeled X, Headline and Active. The first of these is a check box, which may be toggled with &button1; click. The second is the headline name of the critic, the third contains the word Active or Inactive. A critic is inactive if the box in the first column is unchecked or the box is checked, but the critic has been snoozed from the to-do pane (see
Any critic for which the box in the first column is unchecked is inactive and will not trigger. In addition any to-do items associated with that critic will be removed from the to-do pane.

note.para: In the current version of &argouml; all critics but one are active by default. The one exception is Remove <class>'s Circular Inheritance.

sect2.para: The current version of &argouml; has a total of 78 critics. They are described in detail by design issue category in the section on the Design Issues… menu (see ).

sect2.para: To the right of the list are a series of fields giving detailed control over individual critics. Selecting a critic in the list on the left will populate the fields for that critic.

warning.para: In the current release of &argouml; there is a known problem with the user interface. When moving down through the list (i.e. selecting a critic below the previously selected one) the fields are populated for the previously selected critic. To get the fields for the desired critic, another critic further down must be selected, making the desired critic the previous critic whose details will then populate the fields on the right.
Selecting items further up the list (i.e. selecting a critic above the previously selected on) does not have this problem.
A consequence of the different behavior when selecting up or down is that the last critic on the list (Make Edge More Visible) can never populate the fields on the right.

sect2.para: The fields on the right are titled Critic Class: and then the full name of the class in &argouml; that implements the critic.
The first field below this title is a text box labeled Headline: giving the complete headline of the critic (which may be truncated in the list on the left).

note.para: In the headline you may see the text <ocl>self</ocl>, which will be replaced by the name of the artifact in question when the critic is triggered.

sect2.para: The next field is a drop-down selector, labeled Priority:. The three options available are High, Medium and Low and specify the priority category of any to-do item generated by this critic.
The next field is labeled MoreInfo: and contains a URL pointing to further information with a button to the right labeled Go to take you to that URL.

caution.para: In the current release of &argouml; there is no further information available, and the Go button is always grayed out and disabled.

sect2.para: The next field is labeled Description: and is a text area with a detailed explanation of what this critic means. If the text is too large for the area a scroll bar is provided to the right.

note.para: In this text area you may see the text <ocl>self</ocl>, which will be replaced by the name of the artifact in question when the critic is triggered.

sect2.para: The last field is a drop-down selector labeled Use Clarifier, with three options, Always, If Only One and Never.

Clarifiers are the icons and wavy red underlines drawn on the actual diagrams to indicate the a critic has triggered. The original intention was to make the mapping from critics to clarifiers to somewhat customizable.

For example one user might make a Missing Name critic show a red underline, another user might turn off the clarifier, or have it draw a wavy green underline or a blue questionmark. Critics with their clarifier's disabled would still produce feedback that is listed in the to-do pane.

caution.para: In the current release of &argouml; this selector has no function, beyond printing a message on the console. It is for future development.

sect2.para: Underneath the fields are three buttons in a horizontal row.

listitem.para: Wake. It is possible to snooze a critic from the to-do pane (see ), which makes the critic inactive for a period. If the critic has been snoozed, this button is enabled and will wake the critic back up again. Otherwise it is grayed out.

tip.para: You can tell a snoozed critic, because in the list on the left it will have the box in the first column checked, but will be shown as inactive in the third column.

listitem.para: Configure. This button is for configuring the critic.

caution.para: In the current version of &argouml; this function is not implemented, and this button is always grayed out. It is for future development.

listitem.para: Edit Network. Right now critics are implemented in java code. That means end-users cannot add new critics.

The idea of a critic network is that they would be a state machine like diagram with several steps. Each step would have condition that together defined the rule that the critic is providing. If the rule fires, then remaining steps would define the steps of the wizard to help the user fix the problem.

The ideas behind this are discussed in Chapter 4 of Jason Robbins PhD disseration ( http://argouml.tigris.org/docs/robbins_dissertation/diss4.html. In particular look at Figure 1-6 in this chapter and the related discussion.

A suggested implementation is that the conditions could be written in OCL against the UML meta-model. A library of predefined conditins and steps would allow end-users to build new critics by combining those in novel ways.

caution.para: In the current version of &argouml; this function is not implemented, and this button is always grayed out. It is for future development.

sect2.para: Finally the bottom right of the dialog contains a button labeled OK. &Button1; click here dismisses the dialog.

sect1.title: The Tools Menu
sect1.para: This menu provides a generic menu attachment point for any plug-ins provided with &argouml;. The standard system has no plug-ins, so this menu entry is grayed out by default.

sect1.title: The Help Menu
sect1.para: This menu provides help on the use of &argouml;. At present it has a single entry.

sect2.title: About Argo/UML
sect2.para: This menu entry brings up the help window for &argouml; (see ).

textobject.para: The help window for &argouml;. There are five tabs along the top labeled Splash, Version, Credits, Contact Info and Legal. The Splash window is shown with the start up picture for &argouml; displayed.

sect2.para: The window has five tabs, which are selected by &button1; click. By default the first tab (Splash) is shown.

listitem.para: Splash. This displays the picture shown when &argouml; starts up.
Version. This provides version information on the various packages that make up &argouml;.
Credits. This details all those who have created &argouml;, including contact details for the various module owners.
Contact Info. This gives the major contact points for the &argouml; project—the web site, Jason Robbins, the developers mailing list.
Legal. A statement of the FreeBSD license which covers all the &argouml; software.

caution.para: The various documentation of the project are not all covered by FreeBSD (which is really meant for software). In particular this manual is covered by the OpenPub license (see ).
